content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 1h40h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli: anything to report?
  • @WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Joshua Nelson: anything to report?
I can write up a report real quick
@apiraino https://hackmd.io/s/BJ_FwXdvO
hi @T-compiler/meeting , triage meeting is starting now. Leave a :wave: to show you’re here

We’ll start off with ~7 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow (Friday April, 30th) rustc steering: perf triage report construction at 10:00 ET (14:00 UTC)
(@rylev you’re still up for running that, right?)
• Next week May, 6th the new stable release 1.52 will be out

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419
    • "A --temps-dir option for specifying where the intermediate files are written" compiler-team#423

pnkfelix said:

  • Tomorrow (Friday April, 30th) rustc steering: perf triage report construction at 10:00 ET (14:00 UTC)

@pnkfelix I'll be there

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Rename -Cllvm-args to something backend agnostic" compiler-team#421
    • "Update the existing musl targets to be dynamically linked." compiler-team#422
    • "Split rustc_mir" compiler-team#426
    • "Add default search path to Target::search()" rust#83800

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking issue for x86 bittest intrinsics" rust#59414
    • "Tracking issue for array::from_ref and array::from_mut" rust#77101
    • "Tracking Issue for 'ordering helpers'" rust#79885
    • "Tracking Issue for vec_extend_from_within" rust#81656
    • "Update BARE_TRAIT_OBJECT and ELLIPSIS_INCLUSIVE_RANGE_PATTERNS to errors in Rust 2021" rust#83213
    • "Stabilize :pat_param and remove :pat2021" rust#83386
    • "Allow setting target_family to multiple values, and implement target_family="wasm"" rust#84072
    • "Stabilize Duration::MAX" rust#84120
    • "Cautiously add IntoIterator for arrays by value" rust#84147
WG checkins
@Esteban Küber anything to report from @WG-diagnostics ? (I’m guessing no, but just want to check)

@WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Joshua Nelson:

Most notable changes

  • Add sample nix shell #1113
  • Mention -Z unpretty=mir-cfg for debugging MIR #1112
  • Mention CI build of LLVM in build instructions #1104
  • Document test input normalization #1098
  • Add quickstart for adding a new optimization #1094
  • Add Polymorphisation paper #1093
  • Suggest using git range-diff #1092

Most notable WIPs

  • Update build instructions for rustdoc #1117
  • Remove requests or suggestions about rebase and fixup contradictory to rust-highfive bot comment #1111
  • Document inert vs active attributes #1110
  • Explain the new valtree system for type level constants. #1097
  • Add a section on keeping things up to date in the git section #1031
Did I already point all of you at #project leads (public) > six years of Rust blog post ?
I just want to make sure everyone has a chance to add their voice to what they think is worth mentioning on that planned post
okay then, on to backport nominations ...

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

  • No backport nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • No backport nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
(so satisfying!)

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 2 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 2 of those are unassigned
  • 70 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 46 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 5 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 2 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 41 P-high, 86 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "HRTBs are unsound: HRTB on subtrait provides HTRB on supertrait with weaker implied bounds." rust#84591
    • higher ranked trait bound (HRTB) unsoundness on Rust stable
probably want to let T-lang know about that one too
I’ll add them to the mix
is this appropriate for @WG-traits ? @nikomatsakis what do you think?
yes
I saw the issue, and I agree with the fact that it's realted to that long-standing issue
that particular issue is top of my list to fix as we improve the trait infrastructure :)
( wait, there is no WG-traits label)
okay, that was going to be my next question: If this is actually a long-standing known issue
WG-compiler-traits
what is the long standing known issue? I.e. what is its number, I don’t think its references on the description?
anyway, I don’t think its actually P-critical, right?
i.e. should be downgraded to P-high. As we would not block a release on this.
I think P-high
okay
next

• "Functions, closures, and HRTB-trait-objects can implement traits such that validity of associated types is never checked." rust#84533
    • related to previous issue #84591
    • note: perhaps not be a regression, faulty code compiles even on 2018-01-01 nightly

nikomatsakis said:

I saw the issue, and I agree with the fact that it's realted to that long-standing issue

oh, maybe you’re saying that #84591 is indeed related to #84533, and that in turn is related to #25860 ?
Same treatment seems appropriate here: tag with WG-compiler-traits, and downgrade to P-high from P-critical.

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
P-high beta regressions

• "rustdoc drops impl Foreign<Local> for Foreign" rust#82465
    • this should be handled by PR #82496 by @GuillaumeGomez
    • The PR is blocked by some compiler error, see stacktrace
    • The PR has work done by @GuillaumeGomez and @Joshua Nelson (also commented by @Vadim Petrochenkov comments) but seems to a bit stuck
    • Perhaps a second look at it?
^ there is no easy fix for this
"some compiler error" is rustdoc mangling resolve
the fix is https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/83761
which i've been working on (on and off) but will probably take 2 weeks of dedicated full time work, which I don't expect to have in the near future
hmm
issue #82465 was injected by PR #80653, right?
it's possible there's some workaround we could add to resolve, but it's also possible there's not, and just finding out will be difficult as well
yes, I believe so
but I wouldn't expect this to be possible to fix without a full revert
that was going to be my question
does the value of the feature from #80653 outweigh the cost of bugs like #82465 ?
(in short term, I mean.)
I think that's a question for the whole team, I don't feel qualified to answer that
(I assume if we reverted, we would reland #80653 after fixing the fallout.)
right, so whole team:

pnkfelix said:

does the value of the feature from #80653 outweigh the cost of bugs like #82465 ?

pnkfelix said:

right, so whole team:

did you mean to ping @T-rustdoc ?
oh you meant whole rustdoc team, not whole compiler team?
yes
If we’re going to revert, we kinda need to decide now
I’m inclined to revert
Just because I don’t know scope of fallout
Can someone talk me out of reverting?
I really like the show deref methods feature but missing impls like this seems like too large a bug to ship.
it's only recursive derefs we'd miss? those are pretty rare, right?

simulacrum said:

it's only recursive derefs we'd miss? those are pretty rare, right?

types deref-ing to Vec are semi-common
i.e. we've had single level derefs for a long time
and Vec derefs to slice
ah
If we revert
#80653 landed in 1.51 though, so we have already shipped...?
it would be on both beta and nightly
is the issue that the resolver ends up in a weird state after some point?
would it be possible to clone it multiple times?
Oh. Is this a stable-to-stable regression?

Aaron Hill said:

is the issue that the resolver ends up in a weird state after some point?

the issue is there are two copies of the resolver with different ideas of which crates are loaded
which I don't think adding more copies would help with :sweat_smile:
the "ideal" fix in my mind is for expand_hir not to consume the resolver
I think reverting the PR and fixing the original issue without having the compiler problem might be simpler
that would keep it available even in later passes, so I don't need to rewrite the entire intra-doc link pass
I think it's stable-to-stable, not sure though
but @Vadim Petrochenkov requested that I have rustdoc be consistent with rustc for now
if its stable-to-stable ...
I think I still want to fix it
sorry
revert it i mean
but its not a slam dunk

simulacrum said:

#80653 landed in 1.51 though, so we have already shipped...?

I take it you’re figuring that if we revert (and do it on nightly and beta, before this next release), then we’ll get bug reports about the methods from recursive Deref mising, right?
that seems less a bug than a missing features :shrug: but I don't feel strongly
Right
I guess it does seem bad because we had it in the release notes :/
Okay so I don’t think anyone has put forward a strong argument against a revert of PR #80653 ?

Joshua Nelson said:

I guess it does seem bad because we had it in the release notes :/

yeah but we’ll fix it
it just will be a few cycles
I’ll self-assign PR #82465 with plan to revert #80653
thanks

pnkfelix said:

it just will be a few cycles

you have much more confidence in me than I do lol
I think if we knew about this issue when the PR was still under review, we would not have landed it. So I think a revert is reasonable.
not enough test on rustdoc unfortunately

Not blaming anyone :smile:
Just pointing out that I don't think we would have landed this with that bug known.
@pnkfelix once revert is done, can you ping me so I can add a test to prevent the regression to show up again please?
if it helps: whatever the fix is will have massive changes to either intra-doc links or resolve, so it won't be appropriate to backport
It would be good to write a regression test for this
ha ha, okay, good to see you are on same page @GuillaumeGomez
mouhahaha
next

• "probe-stack=inline-asm generates wrong DWARF information" rust#83139
    • @nagisa handled backporting of https://reviews.llvm.org/D99579 in PR #84270
    • and @pnkfelix with PR #83412
so this is partially fixed now that #84270 is landed
There is a new issue related to probe-stack=inline-asm #84667
Hmm
thanks, that wasn’t tagged with T-compiler
So, we reverted PR #77885, didn’t we?
did it get relanded?
It was disabled on stable AFAIR.
oh, right
we only disabled on stable
shoot
ugh
bleah
the revert PR, #83412, was meant to buy us enough time to either fix the bug or decide whether one can rely on quality of dwarf output
but #84667 isn’t even about dwarf
Yeah, this seems much more serious than just some messed up debuginfo
so … I think this means we need to revert #77885 again
and maybe do it more broadly?
Revert on beta & nightly?
yeah that’s what I’m wondering
there is some discussion of ub on the issue?
Stable release is next week. Doesn't seem worth making a new release just to get the fix out a few days sooner.
yeah there’s a claim "The binprintf contains undefined behaviour because result of a bitwise shift is not representable (which may or may not be relevant to the issue if any)."
but a revert does not seem out of order

Wesley Wiser said:

Stable release is next week. Doesn't seem worth making a new release just to get the fix out a few days sooner.

wait, I don’t understand this response
I’m suggesting we revert on current beta and current nightly
Oh has this not hit stable yet?
so that the release won’t have the bug
We reverted #77885 in PR #83412, which was 1.51
Got it, should have checked the issue labels.
Its good to be clear about this
so: Anyone want to talk me out of reverting #77885 across the board?
No, reverting seems like the right call. Maybe we can try this again with the next LLVM version.
LLVM 13?
Assuming it's fixed for that.
Oh, that was sort of a joke. I thought you might mean a point release or something
I cannot remember the cadence of LLVM releases
I guess I'm feeling a bit skittish as this actually results in broken codegen not just some bad DWARF.
the latest one is definitely changing assembly?

The change of push %rax to sub $0x8,%rsp, clobbers SF which is used by sets %r15b.

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/84667#issuecomment-828999841
that’s my interpretation
Self-assigned issue #84667 to cover the reverts.
next

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • "Type annotations needed error on definition site" rust#84398
    • @Jack Huey submitted patch #84559 (unassigned, waiting for a review)
(assigned to @nikomatsakis)
yeah, I think niko will get around to it
I’m not worried about this
next

Performance logs

2021-04-28 triage logs

It's always nice to have a week without any regressions and 2 small improvements :tada::tada:.
I'll bug him :)

Triage done by @rylev.

0 Regressions, 2 Improvements, 0 Mixed, 0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Improvements

  • Use arrayvec 0.7, drop smallvec 0.6 #84420
  • Update grab bag #84498

Mixed

Nags requiring follow up

  • There has still been no follow up to last week's issue.
I can take a look at that
thanks @Aaron Hill !

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "lldb tests only run on macos" rust#81813
    • nominated by @pnkfelix see comment about debuginfo tests breakage
heh. I nominated this because I hit debuginfo tests breaking on my local box
what is right next step? @simulacrum should I be engaging with T-infra about this?
The suggestion in the issue is that we might be able to “easily” change the config of one Linux host
hm
if it's true then a PR should be sufficient
I agree that it should not be necessary to build lldb from source for testing
probably the aux builder or so
okay. if a PR is sufficent, not a team meeting or anything
then maybe I’ll just follow up with you or others from T-infra
to find out what I need to do
to resolve this
thanks!
next
• Special case: highfive#278
this is a PR filed by petrochenkov nearly six months ago
it was a good idea
but closed due to inactivity
I want to revive it, but I also wanted to doa. duoble-check
maybe the list shuld be further revised
Shouldn't that be using the rust-lang/team API?
instead of duplicating the various team lists
(to be fair I’m not sure that nnethercote can do reviews. And I don’t know if RalfJung wants to be included in rotation.)
highfive in general, not that speciic PR

Aaron Hill said:

instead of duplicating the various team lists

that’s a reasonable point
yeah, I mean, it should, but that's not always easy
e.g., T-libs and libs review lists are not the same

Perhaps an exclusion list on top of the data from the teams API would be better long term.

I suspect we will be able to manually generate revised list and merge it much sooner than that would be implemented though.
and generally, that's pretty annoying to get right (when mapping to e.g. individual directories)
Lets try to resolve this
maybe in a dedicated zulip topic?
In general, this has a :thumbs_up: from me.
spawned off to #t-compiler > highfive review membership
(Also, I am vaguely worried about a general imbalance of review load)

(its good to expand the list as a way to try to deal with that. But we may want to start trying to gather data about review load. I’m not sure how best to do so. I.e., its easy to imagine metrics, like “how many PR’s each person r+’es”, and maybe the size of each such PR, but that doesn’t convey stress levels.
anyway, its something to think about. If anyone has knowledge of what other projects do to measure review load and stress from review load, I’d love to hear about it.

T-libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for T-libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
"prs open waiting on review" might be an ok starting point for review load
oh yes, I definitely think it would be good to have data on how long PR’s are waiting in someone’s queue
at the same time, I don’t want to turn it into something where people feel judged
for letting something sit
its more that it is potentially a way to tell if someone is overloaded, even by non-review activities.
it might be a good starting point to find areas where it would help to build up additional experts
yep
Oh, by the way; Hi @mw
:wave:
I also think making better use of the individual directories feature would be great
Yeah I don’t think I knew about that.
i.e. even if someone doesn't have the time to do general reviews, if they think they have time to review PRs for specific bits of code, that could reduce the review stress on the project as a whole
Is there a way to ask rfcbot highfive to roll for another reviewer? Sometimes I get assigned stuff and while I know I'm not the right person to review it, I don't know who to assign it to.
Perhaps we should have a Friday discussion about this?
Okay so lets continue the highfive conversation in #t-compiler > highfive review membership
I think that feature has been requested but not implemented @Wesley Wiser
and I’m going to say that this meeting is itself over. :)
/me needs more :coffee:
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/w9tJSQkHTZWYet3BUijtTA?view

Scheduled checkins from @wg-incr-comp and @WG-llvm
